title: Sister of murdered schoolgirl April Jones reveals she 'lost her mum as well as her sister' in heartbreaking aftermath
text:
Sister of murdered schoolgirl April Jones reveals she 'lost her mum as well as her sister' in heartbreaking aftermath Jazmin Jones' mum struggled to cope in the aftermath of the five-year-old's murder Share By Richard Wheatstone Hayley Minn 11:02, 22 FEB 2017 Updated 11:05, 22 FEB 2017 TV Video Loading Video Unavailable Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Watch Next Tom Jones opens up on wife's death on Lorraine Watch this video again Watch Next April Jones' mum shares final family video of smi 0:31 Woman trashes Pizza Hut after they 'got her order 0:54 Lucy Fallon feels 'too uncomfortable' to watch Be 0:40 Anna Williamson on her anxiety disorder and hitti 0:32 Gareth Gates and Fay Brookes deny faking their OK 0:49 Video will play in Jazmin Jones says mum was 'lost to depression' after April's murder Share this video Watch Next Share Get celebs The sister of murdered schoolgirl April Jones has revealed the heartbreaking effect losing her had on the entire family.
April vanished near her home in Machynlleth, Powys, Wales, in October 2012 when she was just five years old, sparking a huge police search with made national headlines.
Her body was never found but local man Mark Bridger was convicted of her 'sexually-motivated' murder in May 2013.
Jazmin Jones, 21, has told how their mum suffered with severe depression in the aftermath of their loved one’s death - which she said meant they “lost their mum as well as their sister”.
(Photo: ITV) (Photo: ITV) Speaking on This Morning , she said: “She went through really bad depression.
“We would go days without seeing her, because she’d just sleep to get through it.
“We lost the mum she used to be. We felt like we’d lost our mum as well as our sister.
“She’s better now, we’ve finally got our mum back.”
Read More Dad who cancelled £10-a-month gym membership hounded by debt collectors threatening court action April Jones' was murdered after being snatched by local man Mark Bridger Meanwhile, Jazmin turned to alcohol as a "release" but quickly saw her habit spiral out of control.
She says she was only able to give up alcohol by focusing her energies into campaigning for tougher laws for sex offenders along with her parents Coral and Paul.
She told BBC Wales: “When I turned 18 I just turned to drink as a sort of release.
“I’d finish work about three or four in the afternoon and I’d go to the pub and drink all night, to the point I didn’t remember who I was, I didn’t remember my name.
“I’d wake up in the morning with cuts and bruises because I’d fallen over the night before.
Coral and Paul Jones arrive with children Jasmin, left, and Harley to watch Mark Bridger's former house being demolished in 2015 “I felt I couldn’t relate to anyone and no-one had been through what I’d been through.
“I was getting so drunk all the time I thought if I carried on I was going to kill myself.”
Paedophile Mark Bridger was convicted of April's murder and jailed for a whole life sentence in May 2013.
Bridger abducted April from outside her home after becoming obsessed with child pornography and Jazmin believes internet search engines should be better policed.
Read More Mentally ill young woman killed herself hours after NHS staff called her a 'f**king waste of space' Jazmin said: “He had over 500 images on his computer of children.
“If he’d been caught with them before and if the internet was monitored better, police could have got to him then and he’d have been on the sex offenders register and there could have been a different outcome for us.”
April's body was never found (Photo: PA) But Jazmin is happy that the petition for “April’s Law” will now finally be discussed by MPs in Westminster on March 13.
Jazmin said it was hard work getting the 100,000 signatures required to get the petition debated.
She said: “It was going really slow and other petitions were flying up and past the 100,000 mark. I thought ‘this petition I’ve started could save a child’s life’ and it wasn’t getting any more signatures.
“So when it finally passed the 100,000 mark I was really excited.
Mark Bridger was convicted of her murder (Photo: Dyfed Powys Police) “It just meant maybe they might listen to us. I know there’s a long way to go, but it’s another small step.
“We’re hopeful it will get the law out and even if it saves one child’s life we’ll prevent another family having to go through what we’ve been through.”
Bridger was jailed for life in May 2013 after being found guilty of the youngster’s abduction and murder in what the judge said was a “sexually motivated” attack.
During his trial, it emerged he possessed 500 sexually explicit images of children on his computer.
